author: funnygiulio
content: hello, i have a question about LatestValidHash, so what is it actually? is it the latest valid block we received from CL or the latest head (maybe not confirmed by fcu)?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: It's the latest valid ancestor of the block that we are currently processing

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: e.g. in a chain p1 <- p2 <- p_inv <- p3 <- p4, the LVH for p4 would be p2

author: tersec
content: One aspect I've noticed is that I've never seen an LVH in cases where the CL sends `p4`, which isn't ready yet (so, one of `SYNCING`/`ACCEPTED` depending on details, but it's caught up with `p2` in an optimistic sync, so it might be able to tell the CL that, well, it's partly caught up.

author: tersec
content: so as an EL gradually state-syncs, it might be able to respond with more and more recent LVHes

author: tersec
content: Being optimistic has a cost for a CL -- it can't really finalize anything yet, which is a major mechanism/trigger for clearing old states from needing to be accessible, for example.

author: potuz
content: wait what do you mean here by the CL not being able to finalize? we can certainly finalize being optimistic and **we will prune** everything from forkchoice once we have finalized, optimistic or not, and some clients will even remove from db the older, non-finalized (therefore orphaned) blocks, optimistic or not, valid or invalid.

author: tersec
content: Does https://github.com/ethereum/execution-apis/blob/main/src/engine/specification.md#payload-validation or some other part of the specs provide enough assurance that `INVALID` can't crop up later, e.g., that either a block is immediately marked invalid or it's never invalid?

author: potuz
content: We can finalize an INVALID block, I'm not denying that. But that will require 2/3 of the validators to vote on an INVALID block

author: potuz
content: We have larger problems in that case than pruning being optimistic

author: tersec
content: okay, in which case, at least that's what I was getting at with "can't". But sure, it's at least internally consistent.

author: potuz
content: Finalization is purely a consensus concept and does not involve execution in anyway more than honest validators could not have voted for a block being optimistic
